mistralai\/Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3:
The movement of avalanches is primarily dictated by gravity. As such, they move downward because that is the direction with the lowest potential energy, not upward. When an avalanche rolls down a hill, it gains speed because of the increasing potential energy as it moves higher, which is later converted into kinetic energy during the downward move. This process results in a large mass of snow moving with great speed.

On the other hand, if an avalanche were to roll up a hill, it would be going against the force of gravity, and the potential energy at the top of the hill would remain constant or even increase since it must be put in work to roll up the hill, unlike the kinetic energy gained on the way down. The lack of conversion of potential energy into kinetic energy at a sufficient level to significantly move the snow mass would be insufficient for an avalanche to roll uphill.

In conclusion, avalanches don't roll uphill because of gravity, making option C the appropriate answer.
#### C) Avalanches don't roll uphill.
